intro.title: interactoMIX
intro.main:
The InteractoMIX platform is a combined effort of the Structural Bioinformatics and the Bioinsilico labs to bring together, and in a comprehensive manner, some of their current web applications.
Thus, it features a set of tools that addresses two major aspects of protein-protein interaction (PPIs) analysis:
  1. Which proteins interact. That is, the study of PPIs as a network of interactions.
  2. How proteins interact. That is, the structural details of an interaction.
The suite tackles some of the top interests in current biomedical research in a user-friendly and intuitive way. Both computational and experimental scientist can expand their knowledge on explicit pathways (in which their proteins of interest are involved), identify key residues related to the function of a particular interaction and, eventually, predict new therapeutic targets and other molecular agents.

SELECT AN APP FROM THE BULLSEYE TO START

iloops.title: iLoops
iloops.main: Based on ArchDB's classification of super-secondary structures (Smotifs), the iLoops Server exploits the funnel-like intermolecular energy landscape theory by mapping information of known PPIs and known non-interacting proteins (NPIs) to predict new protein-protein interactions.
iloops.aim: Assess the probability of a pair of proteins to interact or not interact.
iloops.in: The user must provide a set of FASTA protein sequences and up to 25 interactions to test. Complementary parameters can be selected depending on the user's interests.
iloops.out: For each requested protein-protein relation, the server provides a boolean prediction as if the relation is PPI or NPI. Furthermore, each prediction can be explored as to examine Smotif relations that statistically favour or disfavour the interaction.

vorffip.title: VORFFIP
vorffip.main: The Voronoi Random Forest Feedback Interface Predictor Server is a structure-based computational method for the prediction of protein binding Voronoi Diagrams that are integrated by a two-steps Random Forest predictor. The method scores the residues of protein structures and evaluates what regions are more likely to interact with other proteins.
vorffip.aim: VORFFIP is the tool of selection to predict protein surfaces that can be involved in protein-protein interactions.
vorffip.in: The basic input required is a PDB coordinate file. A part from that the user is able to tweak some paramenters in order to better fit their needs.
vorffip.out: A Jmol panel is given to the user mapping VORFFIP scores over the protein's surface. Furthermore, both the scores and a new coordinate file (PDB) with recalculated B-factors are provided to the user for download.

mvorffip.title: M-VORFFIP
mvorffip.main: Multi-VORFFIP is a structure-based, machine learning, computational method designed to predict protein-protein, protein-peptide, protein-DNA and protein-RNA binding sites. M-VORFFIP integrates a wide and heterogeneous set of residue- and environment-based information using a two-step Random Forest ensemble classifier.
mvorffip.aim: A typical use of M-VORFFIP is the prediction of functional sites for protein-, peptide-, DNA-, RNA-binding that can be used to guide experimental efforts such as functional mapping of sites in proteins or directed mutagenesis.
mvorffip.in: A simple PDB coordinate file is the only input required by the server.
mvorffip.out: Prediction scores for the residues of the protein and for each of the four binding targets are given to the user as well as Jmol representations for each one of them. All the produced data can be downloaded by the user for further study.

vdock.title: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK
vdock.main: V-D2OCK is focused in the prediction of protein-protein complexes, designed to perform quaternary structure modelling at genome-wide interactome scale. The server uses the V-Patch algorithm to exploit VORFFIP's detection of protein-protein interfaces to guide PatchDock to perform directed dockings. Finally, the predicted poses are clustered in terms of their RMSD using the GROMOS algorithm
vdock.aim: The server is of interest for those users who, given the structure of two individual monomers, wants to model the quaternary structure of the protein complex. Its relative speed makes it specially interesting for those aiming for genome-wide studies.
vdock.in: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK requires two PDB coordinate files to perform the docking. Additionally, the user can select extra scoring functions, the ability to add hidrogens to each structure and the tolerance to cluster decoys.
vdock.out: The server provides with tables detailing the predicted interaction sites as well as images of the best scored quaternary structures. As with the other servers, all the generated data can be downloaded by the user for further exploring.
